title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — On a night where defense reigned supreme, one man’s historic performance carved his name into the record books. In a 100-74 rout of the Houston Rockets, Indiana Pacers center Rik Smits delivered a masterclass, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 44 points in a dominant display at Market Square Arena.

From the opening tip, this was the “Dunking Dutchman’s” showcase. Smits was unstoppable, a 7-foot-4 force operating with impunity in the paint. The Rockets had no answer for his array of post moves, feathery touch from mid-range, and relentless presence. He wasn't just scoring; he was efficient, needing only 24 shots to reach his monumental total. Smits also chipped in 10 rebounds to complete a powerful double-double, personally outscating the entire Rockets starting lineup for long stretches of the contest.

While Smits provided the offensive fireworks, the Pacers' defense collectively strangled the life out of Houston. The Rockets, held to a paltry 74 points, were led by Clyde Drexler’s 17 points, but shot a miserable 32% from the field as a team. The Pacers' supporting cast, including Reggie Miller’s 16 points, provided just enough secondary scoring to complement Smits’ historic night, but this game was a one-man symphony.

For the Pacers, the victory was a statement. For Rik Smits, it was immortality. On this night in 1997, he didn’t just beat the Houston Rockets; he authored a performance for the ages, a franchise record that would stand as the ultimate testament to his skill and a night Indiana would never forget.
